eic_example2.c File Reference

Detailed Description

External Interrupt Controller Example.

  • Compiler: IAR EWAVR32 and GNU GCC for AVR32
  • Supported devices: All AVR32 devices with a Power Manager.
  • AppNote:

Author:
Atmel Corporation: http://www.atmel.com
Support and FAQ: http://support.atmel.no/

Definition in file eic_example2.c.

#include <avr32/io.h>
#include "compiler.h"
#include "gpio.h"
#include "pm.h"
#include "board.h"
#include "eic.h"
#include "intc.h"

00195   // Enable edge-triggered interrupt.
00196   eic_options[0].eic_mode   = EIC_MODE_EDGE_TRIGGERED;
00197   // Interrupt will trigger on falling edge.

00199   // Initialize in synchronous mode : interrupt is synchronized to the clock

00208   // Interrupt will trigger on falling edge.

00211   eic_options[1].eic_async  = EIC_SYNCH_MODE;

00216   // Activate LED0 & LED1 pins in GPIO output mode and switch them off.

00218   gpio_set_gpio_pin(LED1_GPIO);

00222   gpio_enable_module_pin(EXT_INT_EXAMPLE_PIN_LINE1,EXT_INT_EXAMPLE_FUNCTION_LINE1);
00223 #elif BOARD==EVK1101

00225   {

00239   // Register the USART interrupt handler to the interrupt controller.
00240   // usart_int_handler is the interrupt handler to register.
00241   // EXAMPLE_USART_IRQ is the IRQ of the interrupt handler to register.
00242   // INT0 is the interrupt priority level to assign to the group of this IRQ.
00243   // void INTC_register_interrupt(__int_handler handler, unsigned int irq, unsigned int int_lev);
00244   INTC_register_interrupt(&eic_int_handler1, EXT_INT_EXAMPLE_IRQ_LINE1, INT0);

00246 #endif
00247 
00248   // On EVK1100, the JOYSTICK External interrupt line is assigned to the NMI.
00249   // Since the NMI is not an interrupt but an exception managed by the CPU, we have
00250   // to make sure that the NMI handler calls our handler: this is done in the
00251   // files exception.S(for GCC) & exception.s82(for IAR); look for the _handle_NMI
00252   // assembly label.
00253 
00254   // Init the EIC controller with the options
00255   eic_init(&AVR32_EIC, eic_options,EXT_INT_EXAMPLE_NB_LINES);
00256 
00257   // Enable the chosen lines and their corresponding interruption feature.
00258 #if BOARD==EVK1100
00259   eic_enable_line(&AVR32_EIC, eic_options[0].eic_line);
00260   eic_enable_interrupt_line(&AVR32_EIC, eic_options[0].eic_line);
00261 #elif BOARD==EVK1101
00262   eic_enable_lines(&AVR32_EIC, (1<<eic_options[1].eic_line)|(1<<eic_options[0].eic_line));
00263   eic_enable_interrupt_lines(&AVR32_EIC, (1<<eic_options[1].eic_line)|(1<<eic_options[0].eic_line));
00264 #endif
00265 
00266   // Enable all interrupts.
00267   Enable_global_interrupt();
00268 
00269   // Loop infinitely, toggling the leds depending on the latest external event.
00270   while(1)
00271   {
00272     switch (key_number)
00273     {
00274       case 1 :
00275         gpio_clr_gpio_pin(LED0_GPIO);
00276         gpio_set_gpio_pin(LED1_GPIO);
00277         key_number = 0;
00278         software_delay();
00279         break;
00280       case 2 :
00281         gpio_set_gpio_pin(LED0_GPIO);
00282         gpio_clr_gpio_pin(LED1_GPIO);
00283         key_number = 0;
00284         software_delay();
00285         break;
00286       default :
00287         gpio_set_gpio_pin(LED0_GPIO);
00288         gpio_set_gpio_pin(LED1_GPIO);
00289         break;
00290     }
00291   }
00292
